item.title: [Comment] De-escalation of adjuvant radiotherapy in HPV-associated oropharyngeal cancer
item.dc:creator: Imran Petkar
item.prism:publicationName: The Lancet Oncology
item.description: Journal: The Lancet Oncology | DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00726-0
item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet Oncology

Authors: Imran Petkar

DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00726-0

Abstract

HPV-associated oropharyngeal carcinoma has a distinct biology and responds favourably to primary radiation (and surgery)-based treatments. The long-term survival benefit is, however, offset by chronic detrimental impact on health-related quality of life for cancer survivors due to treatment-related toxic effects such as dysphagia and xerostomia. Consequently, many toxicity-mitigating de-escalation methods are being explored for HPV-associated oropharyngeal carcinoma.1 Minimally invasive primary transoral surgery followed by de-intensification of post-operative (chemo) radiation depending on pathological risk assessment is one such investigational approach.

item.title: [Comment] Retraction and republication—De-escalation of adjuvant radiotherapy in HPV-associated oropharyngeal cancer
item.dc:creator: The Lancet Oncology Editors
item.prism:publicationName: The Lancet Oncology
item.description: Journal: The Lancet Oncology | DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00725-9
item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet Oncology

Authors: The Lancet Oncology Editors

DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00725-9

Abstract

In September, 2025, The Lancet Oncology published results of the phase 3 MC1675 study on de-escalated adjuvant radiotherapy versus standard adjuvant treatment for human papillomavirus-associated oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.1 After publication, the corresponding author alerted us to numerical errors present in table 1 caused by a mistranscription of the number of patients in each category of nodal staging by AJCC 7th edition staging and AJCC 8th edition staging. These errors did not affect other data, findings, or interpretation in the paper and we have thus corrected the online version as of Dec 22, 2025.

item.title: [News] Gavi hits HPV vaccine milestone early but concerns surround future funding
item.dc:creator: Tony Kirby
item.prism:publicationName: The Lancet Oncology
item.description: Journal: The Lancet Oncology | DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00712-0
item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet Oncology

Authors: Tony Kirby

DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00712-0

Abstract

Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, a public–private global health partnership with the goal of increasing access to immunisation in developing countries, is celebrating after working with lower-income countries to reach a key target to vaccinate millions of girls with the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine for cervical cancer in mid-November, 2025—6 weeks ahead of its original 3-year target.

item.title: [News] New South Wales expands cancer coverage for firefighters
item.dc:creator: Kark Gruber
item.prism:publicationName: The Lancet Oncology
item.description: Journal: The Lancet Oncology | DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00713-2
item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet Oncology

Authors: Kark Gruber

DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00713-2

Abstract

On Nov 21, 2025, a ministerial media release announced a new legislation passed through Australian Parliament, expanding presumptive workers' compensation coverage for firefighters diagnosed with cancer. The new legislation extends the current list of 12 recognised malignancies in New South Wales, Australia, to include ten new cancers, including primary site lung, pancreatic, thyroid, and skin cancers. Reproductive cancers including cervical, ovarian, uterine, vaginal, vulval, and penile were also included.

item.title: [Policy Review] International consensus recommendations and alignment of terminology for the histopathological diagnosis of extranodal extension in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: an HN-CLEAR initiative
item.dc:creator: Ruta Gupta, Timothy Fielder, Munita Bal, Simion I Chiosea, Jane E Dahlstrom, Aanchal Kakkar, Katalin Kiss, Jan Laco, Neha Mittal, Sunil Pasricha, Spinder Samra, Nina Zidar, Martin Bullock, Rebecca Chernock, William Faquin, Mary S Richardson, D Neil Hayes, Shao Hui Huang, Jean Yang, Ziyad Alsugair, Nazim Benzerdjeb, Shaun Chou, Caroline Cooper, Katarina Dimnik, Rimlee Dutta, Ricardo Santiago Gomez, Juan C Hernandez-Prera, Meenakshi Kamboj, Tina Klitmøller Agander, Ankur Kumar, Jenny T H Lee, Diana M Bell, Toshitaka Nagao, Masato Nakaguro, Timothy Onyuma, Ji Hyun Park, Jin Woo Park, Asawari Patil, Miroslav Podhola, Swapnil Rane, Sean A Rasmussen, Tomáš Rozkoš, Prarthna Shah, Divakar Sharma, Stefi Stefi, Antje Stubsgaard, Ana Cristina Tetzner, Bruce M Wenig, William H Westra, Laura Wise, Sun Och Yoon, HN-CLEAR steering committee and clinical advisory group

item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet Oncology

Authors: Ruta Gupta, Timothy Fielder, Munita Bal, Simion I Chiosea, Jane E Dahlstrom, Aanchal Kakkar, Katalin Kiss, Jan Laco, Neha Mittal, Sunil Pasricha, Spinder Samra, Nina Zidar, Martin Bullock, Rebecca Chernock, William Faquin, Mary S Richardson, D Neil Hayes, Shao Hui Huang, Jean Yang, Ziyad Alsugair, Nazim Benzerdjeb, Shaun Chou, Caroline Cooper, Katarina Dimnik, Rimlee Dutta, Ricardo Santiago Gomez, Juan C Hernandez-Prera, Meenakshi Kamboj, Tina Klitmøller Agander, Ankur Kumar, Jenny T H Lee, Diana M Bell, Toshitaka Nagao, Masato Nakaguro, Timothy Onyuma, Ji Hyun Park, Jin Woo Park, Asawari Patil, Miroslav Podhola, Swapnil Rane, Sean A Rasmussen, Tomáš Rozkoš, Prarthna Shah, Divakar Sharma, Stefi Stefi, Antje Stubsgaard, Ana Cristina Tetzner, Bruce M Wenig, William H Westra, Laura Wise, Sun Och Yoon, HN-CLEAR steering committee and clinical advisory group

DOI: 10.1016/S1470-2045(25)00535-2

Abstract

Histopathologically detected extranodal extension leads to upstaging and treatment escalation in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. There is considerable variation in the prevalence of histopathologically detected extranodal extension in comparable studies. The Head and Neck Cancer International Group, which includes 23 organisations managing patients with head and neck cancer, identified several challenges in evaluating histopathologically detected extranodal extension. Thus, the Head and Neck Consensus Language for Ease and Reproducibility (HN-CLEAR) and its global stakeholders prioritised developing diagnostic criteria and uniform terminology for histopathologically detected extranodal extension.

item.title: [Comment] Is proton therapy a new standard of care for oropharyngeal cancer?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Jensen, Cai Grau
item.prism:publicationName: The Lancet
item.description: Journal: The Lancet | DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(25)02639-X
item.content:encoded:
Journal: The Lancet

Authors: Kenneth Jensen, Cai Grau

DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(25)02639-X

Abstract

The study by Steven J Frank and colleagues1 in The Lancet is the first randomised, phase 3 trial comparing intensity-modulated proton therapy (IMPT) with intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) in patients with oropharyngeal cancer. Support for the role of proton radiotherapy for head and neck cancer has previously come from dosimetric studies,2 as well as retrospective and case–control clinical reports.3–5 A study with early experience from the MD Anderson Cancer Center compared 50 patients treated with IMPT with 100 patients treated with IMRT, finding a significant reduction in acute gastrostomy tube use and severe weight loss with IMPT, but no difference in tumour control.

Journal: The Lancet

Authors: Steven J Frank, Paul M Busse, J Jack Lee, David I Rosenthal, Mike Hernandez, David M Swanson, Adam S Garden, G Brandon Gunn, Samir H Patel, James W Snider, Daniel J Ma, Jason K Molitoris, Nancy Y Lee, Upendra Parvathaneni, Mark W McDonald, Noah S Kalman, Alexander Lin, Nasiruddin Mohammed, Christina Henson, Christian Hyde, Gopal K Bajaj, Sanford R Katz, Roi Dagan, William H Morrison, Jay P Reddy, C David Fuller, Shalin J Shah, Jack Phan, Gregory M Chronowski, Lauren Mayo, Erich M Sturgis, Renata Ferrarotto, Xiaorong R Zhu, Xiaodong Zhang, Li Wang, Katherine A Hutcheson, Adel K El-Naggar, Amy C Moreno, Anna Lee, Michael T Spiotto, Neil D Gross, Stephen Y Lai, Jay J Liao, Jonathan Paly, Zhongxing Liao, Robert L Foote, The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center Clinical Trial Consortium

DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(25)01962-2

Abstract

IMPT showed non-inferiority to IMRT for progression-free survival, improvement in overall survival, similar disease control, and reduced high-grade toxicity relative to IMRT. Treatment-related and post-progression deaths occurred more frequently with IMRT. IMPT is a new standard-of-care treatment option for patients with oropharyngeal cancer.

item.title: Unexpected Results of Induction Chemotherapy vs Adjuvant Chemotherapy
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoncol.2025.4092
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoncol.2025.4092

Abstract

To the Editor We read with interest the results of the phase 3 randomized clinical trial by Guo et al that investigated the important question if induction chemotherapy (IC) was superior to adjuvant chemotherapy (AC) when added to a backbone of concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) in patients with N2-3 nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). For IC, the investigators used the triplet combination of paclitaxel-cisplatin-fluorouracil (TPF), whereas doublet cisplatin-fluorouracil (PF) was used for AC. The trial was powered to detect a 12% difference in progression-free survival (PFS) in favor of IC, and enrolled 324 patients, with 162 patients in each group. However, this was a negative trial with comparable 3-year PFS between IC plus CCRT and CCRT plus AC, contrasting the results of the NPC-0501 trial by the Hong Kong NPC study group, which showed an improvement for PFS in favor of IC, albeit subtle differences exist between both trials. Intriguingly, in the present study, IC was associated with poorer local control compared with AC.

item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3256

Abstract

Mission Statement: To advance the patient-centered, evidence-based practice of otolaryngology–head and neck surgery by publishing scientifically rigorous and innovative research, reviews, and commentary. Our journal serves as a vital resource for clinicians, researchers, educators, and trainees by providing high-quality, peer-reviewed content focused on improving the understanding and treatment of ear, nose, and throat conditions. We are dedicated to fostering dialogue and action on critical issues in otolaryngology, including the education and training of health care professionals, quality improvement, and the ethics and economics of equitable health care delivery.

item.title: Updated Calcitonin Thresholds More Accurately Predict Lymph Node Metastasis?
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.4013
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.4013

Abstract

To the Editor I read with great interest the recent study by Du et al, “Updated Thresholds of Basal Calcitonin Level and Extent of Lymph Node Metastasis in Initially Treated Medullary Thyroid Cancer,” and the accompanying Invited Commentary. However, the results reported in Table 2 appear internally inconsistent, possibly due to transposing of the sensitivity and specificity columns for American Thyroid Association (ATA) serum calcitonin thresholds of 20, 50, and 500 pg/mL (to convert to picomoles per liter, multiply by 0.292); however, for 200 pg/mL, they seem correct. The ATA thresholds were originally chosen to minimize the false negative rate. In this context, the reported very low sensitivity for the 50 pg/mL cutoff—implying a very high false negative rate—is implausible, as is the correspondingly very high specificity; the same applies for the cutoff values of 50 and 500 pg/mL.

item.title: Updated Calcitonin Thresholds More Accurately Predict Lymph Node Metastasis?—Reply
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.4010
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.4010

Abstract

In Reply We thank Colli for his thoughtful comments on our study. We would like to provide a detailed clarification to address what we believe a misunderstanding regarding our updated thresholds. First, we fully agree that the ATA thresholds seek to minimize missed LNMs by adopting very low preoperative calcitonin cutoffs. However, this inevitably leads to an extremely high rate of overtreatment, resulting in unnecessary complications and surgical morbidity. For example, under the current cutoffs, patients newly diagnosed with medullary thyroid cancer and with preoperative calcitonin greater than 20 pg/mL would be considered for lateral neck dissection. In our data, patients with calcitonin levels of 20 to 50 pg/mL had 5-year structural recurrence-free survival rates of 92.1% and 100% in the training and validation cohorts, respectively, with no recurrences observed in the validation cohort, comparable to 92.7% and 93.0% in the 241.9 to 693.9 pg/mL group. Thus, prophylactic neck dissection in patients with calcitonin levels of 20 to 50 pg/mL would likely lead to substantial overtreatment.

item.title: Oral Steroids for Postthyroidectomy Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3874
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3874

Abstract

To the Editor We read the randomized clinical trial by Carvajal-Alegria et al with great interest. The authors are to be commended for conducting a rigorous placebo-controlled trial on the use of oral corticosteroids for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (UVFP) following thyroid surgery. While their findings suggest no benefit on vocal fold remobilization, we believe this conclusion warrants discussion regarding 4 critical aspects: the therapeutic window, injury-specific mechanisms, patient-centered end points, and the potential of multimodal therapy.

item.title: Oral Steroids for Postthyroidectomy Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3880
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3880

Abstract

To the Editor Unilateral postoperative vocal cord paralysis is a rare (3.5%) complication that is typically temporary. It is frequently caused by neurapraxia of the recurrent laryngeal nerve as a result of manipulation, traction, or inflammation during surgery. Glucocorticoids have demonstrated clinically significant improvement in cases of neurapraxia with facial paralysis.

item.title: Caution Comparing Transoral Ultrasonography With Postbiopsy Magnetic Resonance Imaging—Reply
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3785
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3785

Abstract

In Reply We appreciate Guenette’s interest in our recent article on the use of surgeon-performed transoral ultrasonography for the diagnostic workup of oropharyngeal cancers. We apologize that there has been an error in the text (for which a correction note has been published), which may have given the impression that magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results were known when transoral ultrasonography was performed. To clarify, the transoral ultrasonography was performed as an extension of the clinical examination during the patient’s first visit to the outpatient cancer clinic. MRI was performed afterwards; therefore, the transoral ultrasonography was blinded to the MRI and biopsy results. Our exclusion criteria also stated that any participants with available cross-sectional imaging at their first visit were not included.

item.title: Protecting the Contralateral Palatine Tonsil
item.prism:publicationName: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
item.description: Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue | DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3318
item.content:encoded:
Journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue

DOI: 10.1001/jamaoto.2025.3318

Abstract

To the Editor We applaud Peterson et al for revisiting the question of whether to routinely remove the nondiseased tonsil during transoral robotic surgery (TORS) for human papillomavirus (HPV)–associated palatine tonsil squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Their well-executed retrospective analysis demonstrates clinically meaningful increases in hemorrhage, 30-day emergency department visits/hospitalizations, and hospital stays after bilateral compared with unilateral palatine tonsillectomy, with similar rates of second primary diagnoses and equivalent survival outcomes. Although previous literature has endorsed routine removal of the contralateral palatine tonsil as standard of care to prevent the emergence of second primary tumors, valid counterpoints to this argument should be considered.
